name: Screening Interview (Phone/Video)
description: A brief initial interview, typically conducted by an HR recruiter over the phone or video, to quickly assess basic qualifications, salary expectations, and overall fit before moving to more in-depth rounds.

name: One-on-One / Traditional Interview
description: A standard, in-person or virtual interview between the candidate and a single interviewer (often the hiring manager). Focuses on general background, experience, and cultural fit.

name: Behavioral Interview
description: Questions focus on past experiences to predict future performance. Uses the STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result) format, with questions like: 'Tell me about a time when you had a conflict with a co-worker.'

name: Situational Interview
description: Presents hypothetical 'what-if' scenarios to gauge problem-solving and decision-making skills in a forward-looking context. Questions often start with: 'How would you handle a situation where...?'

name: Technical / Skills-Based Interview
description: Used primarily for technical roles (e.g., software engineering, data science). Focuses on specific domain knowledge, coding ability, and problem-solving through live exercises or tests.

name: Panel Interview
description: The candidate is interviewed by multiple interviewers (a 'panel') simultaneously. This format saves time and allows the candidate to be assessed by several stakeholders at once.

name: Group Interview
description: Multiple candidates are interviewed together, often participating in a collaborative task or discussion. Used to assess teamwork, communication, and leadership skills under pressure.

name: Case Interview
description: The candidate is presented with a business problem or scenario (a 'case') and asked to analyze it and propose a solution. Common in consulting and strategy roles to test analytical thinking.

name: Stress Interview
description: The interviewer intentionally creates a challenging or high-pressure atmosphere (e.g., challenging answers, long silences) to assess the candidate's composure, resilience, and response to stress.

name: Final / Executive Interview
description: The last stage of the process, often with a senior leader or executive. It typically confirms cultural fit, long-term goals, and alignment with the company's high-level vision.
